captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
-Hey, everyone.
It's Brooklyn and Bailey.

And today, we decided
to do a 4th of July

craft because here
in the United States

in the next couple
of days, we are
celebrating the 4th of July.

So we are downstairs
in the kitchen,
because the craft involves food.
So let's get started.
OK.

First off, we're going
to do two different kinds
of red, white, and blue drinks.

The first one is red
and blue layered.
And the second one is--
-Berry ice.

-They're like, red,
white and blue berry ice.

So the first thing to do for
the red and blue layered drink

is you want to almost
overflow your glass with ice.

-Because ice is the only
thing stopping the two colors

from meshing together, so
ice is very, very important.
-Yes.

So then you want to take
your cranberry juice

and pour maybe like
this much in your glass,

because the blue
sometimes doesn't
work if you put a lot of red in.
-That's probably good.

-Then you'll take your
blue Gatorade Frost

and you pour it over
the ice really slowly,
just so that it won't mesh.

-And, as you can see,
it's now a blue and red--
-Drink.
- layered drink.
-There you go.
-Now we'll start with mine.

So to start off, we'll explain
how we made the berry ice.

All you need is an ice tray and
raspberries and blueberries.

And you just fill the
ice tray full of water

and stick the berries
inside of the ice.
-The ice.
-And you freeze it like that.

So then it comes out with the
raspberries and blueberries
frozen inside of the ice cube.
-They look pretty cool.

-We'll start by putting a
bunch of our homemade ice
inside of the drink.

And again, you'll
want to overflow it,
but this time it's just for fun.

-I bet you can probably
eat the berries once it--
-Yeah, once it freezes.
- --unfreezes.
-I mean, unfreezes.
There we go.

And then we'll just
take our Gatorade Frost
and pour it into our cup.

-And there you have your red,
white, and blue berry ice.

And just for fun, we used
red vines as our straws.

We just cut the tops
and bottoms off.
-Yeah.

Just cut the ends and the tops
off, and there are your straws.

-Next, we're going to
be doing like, a fruit--
-Flag.
- --American flag.

Like, the red, white, and
blue stripes and stars.
-Yeah.

And the products you need
are just strawberries,

and you'll just
cut those in half.

Bananas, and you'll
just slice them.

And then blueberries, and
you'll just leave those alone.

And then you need
some kabob sticks
and a tray to hold your flag.

-There's two different
kinds of kabob
sticks you will be making.

The first one is the beginning
of the flag that has like,
blue with the stars.
So you'll use blueberries.

-And then the second
half is the part
where it's just red and white.
-OK.

You'll want to start-- so
you'll put a banana on.

You want to put it on lengthwise
and just stick it up there.

And push it up so
it's about maybe
a little more than halfway.

And you'll take the strawberry
and you'll put it on,
push it up next to the banana.

Take another banana,
stick it through.
Strawberry.
Stick it through.

And then on the top, you'll
want to do four, maybe five,

blueberries just to
put the blue in there.
Four and five.

And then you'll just
set it down on your pan

and you will do three
other kabob sticks of this.

So do you want to show them
how to do the next one?
-OK.

So mine is the part of the flag
where it's just red and white.

So we'll start
with the strawberry

on the bottom like this, and
then we'll put on a banana.
Strawberry.
Banana.
Strawberry.
And you'll just keep going.

So there should be four
strawberries and three bananas.
Like this.

And that will go on
the end of the flag.

And we'll just keep doing
this and building our flag.

As you can see, we just
finished our fruit American flag
for the 4th of July.
There you go.
You can see it better.

-Don't forget to follow us on
Instagram @BrooklynandBailey.

-And we will see
you guys next week.
Bye.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
-Just go like this.
How's the kabob?
-Pretty good.
Juicy.
-What?
-Juicy.
-Oh, I thought you said goose-y.
I don't know.
-Goose-y.
